title: The Hawaiian story of the wind keepers - Sydney Iaukea

multiple-choice.question: Who was La'amaomao in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: The king's most trusted attendant

options.label: B
options.text: The Hawaiian wind goddess

options.label: C
options.text: Paka'a's wife

options.label: D
options.text: Kuapaka'a's friend

multiple-choice.question: Why did the two navigators turn the king against Paka'a?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Paka'a was not doing his job properly

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were jealous of Paka'a's position and skills

options.label: C
options.text: Because Paka'a was plotting against the king

options.label: D
options.text: Because Paka'a was not loyal to the king

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the wind gourd in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a symbol of the king's power

options.label: B
options.text: It was a tool for navigation

options.label: C
options.text: It housed the winds of the Islands and held La'amaomao's bones and life force

options.label: D
options.text: It was a gift from the king to Paka'a

multiple-choice.question: How did Kuapaka'a prove himself to the king?

options.label: A
options.text: By winning a canoe race

options.label: B
options.text: By showing his knowledge of the winds

options.label: C
options.text: By defeating the two navigators

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome for Paka'a at the end of the story?

options.label: A
options.text: He was banished from the kingdom forever

options.label: B
options.text: He was restored to his position and lands

options.label: C
options.text: He became the new king

options.label: D
options.text: He was forgotten by the king and the people
